reviewText: The other reviewers have already supplied the general plot details, so I'll just add my overall opinion.  As my review title states, there is more talk than action, but the action sequences are good and entertaining.  One sore spot with me is that Bruce Willis was given first billing as the star, yet in the film he is nothing more than a paper pusher office detective who does not see any action.  He contributes very little to the general plot, and ZERO to the few action sequences.  Gosh, the producers could have used a fifth-rate, unknown actor from Iowa at 5% the cost of Willis, and the plot would have moved along just as well.  But I guess they just wanted to capitalize on his famous name, not caring that they were actually deceiving the movie viewers.  Makes me think this macho-man hero is getting too old and can't fight bad guys anymore (just like Steven Siegal).  No more Willis movies for me. This movie was a general disappointment.
summary: Too Much Talk, Not Enough Action...

reviewText: The acting is convincing especially the actors who play the lawyer and David Hagan. They make me really hate the characters.There are some touching scenes. For example the scene relates to Jeremy’s lover in the first 20 minutes of the movie. The dialogue between them is funny and interesting too.The action scenes in the first 30 minutes are gripping and suspenseful.It is outrageously far-fetched with gigantic logical holes. It depicts one ex-fire fighter who successfully fights against the whole group of professional criminals. Yeah right!It is absolutely predictable from the beginning till the end. I do not know why the criminals who killed cops in the past became so stupid when they confronted the fireman.In summary, it is worth watching once for fun. Just put your logic to sleep while at it
summary: Highly Entertaining + Convincing acting + Some Gripping Action scenes + Absolutely Predictable + Some Touching Scenes

reviewText: Josh Duhamel stars in this fairly star-studded cast about a California fireman who's taken into witness protection after witnessing a brutal murder in a convenience store. The murderer ends up being a big time white supremacist, played by a scary and superb Vincent D'Onofrio. The opening scene involving a fire was stunningly show, suggesting the film would be a surprise, but as soon as the dialog began I was slightly disappointed. The acting is overall great, but some of the dialog and situations didn't seem natural. Otherwise the film was highly entertaining and great to look at.Source: criticnic.com 17 November 2012Disclosure: film sent by Lionsgate
summary: A lot of good elements, but could have been much better

reviewText: FIRE with FIRE follows a simple, straightforward plot with no huge turnabouts or surprises, even though there are a number of good smaller ones. An interesting entanglement of local cops, firemen, U.S. Marshals, Crips, and white supremacists. Generally good cinematography and acting: Though I've never been a big Bruce Willis fan, his role here fits him well. Good supporting cast and characters, particularly Kevin Dunn as Agent Mullens. Though the film starts out promisingly, it later degenerates into a series of predictabilities, unrealisms, too-easies, and general corninesses, with dialogue that becomes flatter and less realistic as it proceeds. Still, it is very difficult to make a film that's totally clean of such elements, and here, as in many others, they do not come close to being completely ruinous. FIRE with FIRE remains a compelling and riveting show, which is what we all expect, right?
summary: Thriller Fans Should Find This Film Worthwhile and May Even Really Dig It

reviewText: Given the familiar story line of "Fire with Fire" it would have taken a good script just to get it to the level of 'same old same old.' But the script here is stupid to the point it barely reaches above bad.Here's the scoop. Jeremy Coleman is a fireman in Long Beach. One night he's in a convenience store when Nazi thugs enter and kill the owner and the owner's son because they won't sign over the store lease.  He escapes and can rat on the group's leader (Vince D'Onofrio) but will need to go into protective custody. He agrees and, in the process, falls for his guardian U.S. Marshall (Rosario Dawson) when everything falls apart. Seems D'Onofrio is very resourceful and can track him and her down and kill both. Now our hero firefighter must fight "Fire with Fire." (right)What a screw-up. This script is dumb beyond the meaning of the word. There are so many lapses in logic and procedure it's difficult to imagine how it ever got a green light. In one scene the marshals leave the hero alone which allows him to escape. Is that S.O.P.? It is also cliche ridden. This scenario has been done before. Many times. You need something really clever to raise it above the fray and that isn't happening here. It's one plodding, dumb scene after another.Bruce Willis is on hand as a detective out to get D'Onofrio. Why is Bruce doing this part? He looks tired and bored. Does he really need the paycheck? I liked Josh Duhamel in "Transformers" but he just doesn't have the gravity to pull off the hero role here. I'm in love with Rosario Dawson but her role here is nowhere near deep enough for her to rap her talent around. The only standout part for me was D'Onoforio. He was the only character written with any depth. The directing never rose above hack level and all the production values were assembly line.I knew this wasn't going to be great when I went in but I expected more than this. I expected at least some level of competency, but it just wasn't happening. Don't waste your time.
summary: This Laps at the Heels of Mediocrity

reviewText: You've seen this flapping turkey before. My biggest complaint is that i bought it instead or renting it via Netflix, cuz this is a one shot deal. Bruce Willis looked like he was on pain killers and never fired a round in this routine good guy on the run from the baddied. I counted three times when the heroes (a fireman who saw murders committed and a nicely-shaped US marshal who falls for the big lug) scuffle and lose their weapons and watch them skid across the smooth floor. Once, maybe, not three times in a movie. Willis could have been replaced with a cardboard cutout and we would have gotten the same visual results. Time for him to retire.One major plus, the bad guy and his pack of blood-thirsty goons are terrific. They radiate evil and you want them to perish by the sword and slowly. I won't give away the main villain's name but he was in 'Full Metal Jacket' and he was masterful as the head whacko - one problem, not enough mayham by the vicious pack of mad dogs to really make them stand out among mad dog movie killeers - still, not too shabby as bad guys often make the film memorable.Basic plot line that has been run over by Hollyweird writers scores of times over the decades, tired dialog and lots of mumbling draw this one down two stars and that modern director's flawed fast, lets strain older viewer's eyeballs type camera work knocks this down another half star. A few loose ends, some decent shoot-em ups (without old Bruce bustin' caps) and some vile baddies waiting to die make this one watchable - one time. Anyone want to buy a slightly used DVD in excellent condition? Only viewed once.
summary: Pretty routine and often bloody cops and robbers

reviewText: I like Josh Duhamel. I thought he made the TV series LAS VEGAS interesting when he was there and he certainly fit the bill when he starred in the TRANSFORMER films. Why he hasn't been used more as a leading man I'll never know, but if his output is limited to direct to DVD films then I don't expect him to become the major player he should.This brings me to FIRE WITH FIRE, the latest direct to DVD flick to highlight the fact it was produced by the same people who brought you RIGHTEOUS KILL and 16 BLOCKS. Come on folks, we really don't care who produces a film because for the most part that's rarely a guarantee that the film will be any good. Fortunately here it turns out that it is.Duhamel plays Jerry Coleman, a good guy and a fire fighter who witnesses a murder at the local quick mart after stopping in for snacks. The owner and his son are shot and killed in front of Jerry and only through some quick thinking does he escape only to be wounded in the process. Jerry goes to the police and with the sketch they do of the suspect the case pulls in Det. Mike Cella (Bruce Willis). The killer is David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio), a white supremacist who killed Cella's partner years ago. Released for that crime, Cella wants desperately to put him behind bars. With Jerry's testimony he can do that.But things start off bad and eventually get worse. While in a line up to be identified, Hagan lets Jerry know he knows who he is and where he can find him. The D.A. offers Jerry witness protection via the U. S. Marshall Service and he takes the offer. His identity erased from all databases and moved to New Orleans, 8 months go by and the trial date is approaching. But that's not all that's happened.While being guarded, Jerry has fallen in love with his protector in the Marshall Service, Talia Durham (Rosario Dawson). A big no no in the Service, she plans on moving back to his home town once the case is settled. Too bad Hagan was able to find their location and send in a hit man to kill them both. With Durham wounded, Jerry is able to contact the Marshall Service for help. Though they plan on protecting him more thoroughly this time a phone call from Hagan prompts Jerry to decide to stop running and take the man on on his own terms.Dropping his agents, Jerry makes his way back home. Knowing that Hagan has been trying to take over turf held by the Crips, Jerry approaches them for a weapon. Once he's armed, he sets out to make sure that he gets Hagan before Hagan can get him.So the revenge film is set in motion and the side characters offer nice support in this film that actually turns out to be quite well done. The look of the film is completely professional and looks slick. The acting is believable by all involved here. And the story isn't near as thin as a number of main stream major releases seen of late.Going in I think that most people will know what to expect from this film. Willis has taken on the duties of packing the deck in a number of low budget films in the past few years and my guess is he's trying to pay back helping others on the way up. His name will draw viewers to this film even though he isn't the main focus of the film. But once you get started with this movie you'll find yourself drawn in and watch from beginning to end. It's not a bad movie and you'll get your money's worth with a rental.
summary: STANDARD DIRECT TO DVD ACTION FLICK

reviewText: The reason I deducted one star was because the ending was left open. I hate when a movie leaves the audience with a question, especially if that question pertains to the status of the main characters. It is a fatal flaw that I believe some film makers do not grasp. If I spend 90 minutes or so watching the story unfold, it makes sense that I am interested in something about the story... Since I am interested in the story, it makes further sense that I want to know about the problems the characters are dealing with, how they respond, and what happens to them. Does the cowboy win the battle and the girl and ride off into the sunset? Does ET call home and get through? Does Batman and Robin escape the trap the Joker snared them in?  That is why I will tune in tomorrow night, same Bat time, same Bat channel. So it kindly torques my constitution when I give the writer/director my undivided time to follow the story, care about the characters, cheer them on and pray they are victorious...only to leave the theater wondering what happened to them. I want the story to have a solid ending, a firm conclusion. I want to know what really happened. The story was a little bit weak in that it was highly implausible. I will not drop spoilers. But I will just say that more time should have been spent on the front end, demonstrating that the hero didn't go from Common Joe to Billy Bad Ass overnight with little or no training. Bruce Willis' role is rather limited and more of a supporting nature. That was a let down as I have grown accustomed use to Bruce kicking bad guy rear-end.Fifty-Cent has a minor supporting role, a cameo really, sporting a 1973 Jim Kelly look, which was kind of comical. I expected him to say: "Man, you come right out of a comic book!"The Fiver-Star winner in this movie was Bonnie Somerville. I was unfamiliar with her prior to this movie. The Irish Catholic from Flatbush, NY is quite the lass. Her supporting role could have been better defined but her screen appeal made up for the shortcomings in the script.Rent it?  YES  Own it?  NAH!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Thank you for reading my review. I hope it was helpful to you.Rob

reviewText: Seems odd to have Bruce Willis and Josh Duhamel yet such a weak script and such an unassuming, joke of a putz for a "bad guy"? He looks more like a janitor or used car salesman than a crime lord! If only they had a bit more quality on the script and a named actor up there with Willis for the "bad guy" this could've been a much better movie. if not for Bruce Willis and Josh Duhamel this wouldn't even be worth watching yet was a real waste of Willis's talents. In the era of bad retreads and just plain unwatchable movies I sat and watched this one which puts it in a certain class I just wish they'd gone the extra mile and a couple extra bucks and made this "great" instead of just "ok".

reviewText: Here's The Lowedown on "Fire with Fire" (An Action/Thriller DVDreview)...LIKED IT!!!Genre: 8 Movie: 7Checkout "The Lowedown" on FacebookWhat's it about?A fireman takes an unexpected course of action when a man whom he'sbeen ordered to testify against, after being held up at a localconvenience store, threatens him.What did I think?Having low expectations gave big rewards on this one.  I have seen afew "straight to dvd titles" with Bruce Willis on the cover only tofind that he only has a small part in the movie.  In this movie, heactually has a primary role and does well with it.  This is asleeper pick to put in your players...enjoy!

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: In Long Beach, there is a turf war going on. Firefighter Jeremy Coleman (Josh Duhamel) is a witness to a murder and has been placed in the witness protection program where he falls in love with a US Marshall (Rosario Dawson). Bruce Willis plays local police chief Mike Cella who would like very much to see crime boss David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio) go to jail.While in the program, the bad guys find out where Jeremy is located and threaten to kill everyone Jeremy knows and their family. Jeremy goes vigilante in order to save himself and everyone else. He also gives us overwhelming clues about the ending.I liked the climax of the film, in spite of the fact I knew it was coming from 30 minutes into the film. The script was overly predictable and the dialouge wasn't moving. Vinnie Jones gives us a brief bad guy, and likewise 50 Cent wasn't on screen that long. I would have liked to have seen more of Willis in the film.Might work as a 99 cent rental for some people. Not a keeper.Parental Guide: F-bombs, implied sex scene, no nudity. Torture. Bullet holes in the head.
summary: YOU GET TO KEEP YOUR FIRST NAME
Title: N/A

reviewText: "I'm a ghost, I don't exist. I'm gonna find you and I'm gonna kill you. I'm gonna disappear and noone is ever gonna know." After stopping at a convenience store and talking to his owner friend Jeremy Coleman (Duhamel) becomes witness to a double murder. When they decide not to kill him Jeremy is left alone to ID the murderer. Not wanting loose ends Jeremy is now a target and he must now fight for his life to survive and also to take care of the killer the the cops have been trying to get for years. I will start by saying that I am a pretty big Bruce Willis fan but he has been very hit or miss lately. I really liked "Catch .44" but thought "Set-Up" was lame. Also as a disclaimer the quote I used is actually from this movie, not from the movie Taken so don't let that confuse you. The movie itself isn't anything new or amazing but it is actually pretty fast paced and keeps you interested and watching the entire time. The movie when you break it down is just another vigilante type revenge movie but again because it's so fast paced and entertaining you can't stop watching. Also Vincent D'Onofrio gives such a great performance in this that watching for just for him is almost enough to keep you till the end. Overall, this is a fast paced exciting action movie that is the perfect kind to just put in and veg out to. I liked it. I give it a B.
summary: A very generic but very fast moving and entertaining vigilante type movie. Great cast and fun to watch. I say B.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brice Willis may be on the DVD jacket, but the star of "Fire with Fire" is Josh Duhamel playing a Los Angeles firefighter Jeremy Coleman in witness protection program. Though he has agreed to testify against a violent mobster David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio), Jeremy decides that it is up to him to protect those he loves from the sociopathic Hagan, so he takes some extreme measures, despite the advice from Rosario Dawson's deputy marshal assigned to the case (who is also Jeremy's girlfriend)."Fire with Fire" is a typical case of straight-to-DVD films, with a few A-list actors in a B movie format. You will notice a wealth of familiar faces like Kevin Dunn, Vinnie Jones and Richard Schiff, all typecast. The story may be as incredible as that of "Collateral Damage," but it is not boring. Actions are not big, but acceptable.In some low-budget action flicks, "name" actors are there to draw the attention of potential customers, but their roles in the actual films are often miniscule or at best extended cameos. In "Fire with Fire" second-billed Bruce Willis is wasted in a pointless role that is slightly better than the ones he played in "Set Up" and "Catch .44."Keep your expectation level low, and you may find "Fire with Fire" pretty good. Except the climax scene (based on a questionable idea about fire and firefighter) the film does not have much new to offer, but is still watchable.
summary: (2.5 STARS) OK B Action Movie with One A-List Actor in a Supporting Role
